quotes.quote: This, communibus annis, makes --- 3741 [avg tons logwood imported to GB per yr in 1713-1716], which they [the lords of trade and platations] computed at 60,000l. per annum value, although the price was then fallen from 40l. to 16. per ton; whereas, before the English settled in these parts, it was bought from foreigners at 100l. per ton. They remarked, that this trade was not less necessary than lucrative and beneficial to the British dominions, by reason of the great encouragement it gives to our seamen and shipping. All this we owe to the Bucaniers, who first established a settlement here, and maintained their ground against a continual annoyance of the Spaniards, though unsupported all the time by any assistance from Great-Britain.
quotes.quote_n: 'Bucaniers' present since at least ca mid 17th cent /v Long v 1 pp 298-300
quotes.note: does not seem similar to Robertson 1777 / rejected by s1644
